It would be a Bancorp v. Bonner situation, because if it became moot as a result of the settlement of the case after the Seventh Circuit's decision, then the Seventh Circuit's decision should stay in place.
So if -- I do not agree that the case is moot, but if hypothetically the case were moot, then we are not in a Munsingwear situation; we are in a Bancorp situation, because the mootness--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's an interesting -- that's an interesting question.
I mean, is it becoming moot through their voluntary cessation or activity when the State law requires them to take particular action?

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: --No, what -- what I'm saying, Your Honor, is if we're -- if we're defining mootness as the ultimate return of the property, then the property was returned pursuant to settlements in four of the cases.
The plaintiffs agreed, we'll pay $400 instead of $20,000, if you return our car.
The car was returned.
So if the case was settled and became moot because of the settlement, it is not a situation in which the Court can adopt the Munsingwear position.
It really is a Bancorp situation, and the Seventh Circuit's decision remains--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, all of these problems really arise out of the fact that the effect of the court of appeals' decision basically was to overrule the motion to dismiss, left everything open on remand.

So if we said it is moot, you'll just get another plaintiff and bring another lawsuit, which is what you do if the Court -- we are trying to get into the case much earlier than we should, it seems to me.
Just let the proceedings go ahead on remand and find out what all the -- all these factual answers that -- or these questions that should be answered.

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: --I certainly agree with that, Your Honor.
The -- there are many--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The mootness -- the mootness decision won't really decide anything.
You'll just say you've got to file another lawsuit and start over again.

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if you just say, we -- probably, in my judgment, we ought to dismiss this writ as improvidently granted and let the record be developed and the case go by, and we could decide the issues.

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: That, it seems to me, is a very wise choice of action.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But where you said -- you said that--

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: For obvious reasons.
But beyond that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --the Seventh Circuit -- your complaint, you say, is -- you asked for the universe, every kind of property of due process hearing within 10 days or a short period.
But you said the Seventh Circuit narrowed the relief.
And I'm looking at the Seventh Circuit decision, and I really don't see what was narrowed.
I think they left everything open for the district Court.

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: --Well, they--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where -- where is there any narrowing?

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: --Well, the narrowing, as I perceive it, Your Honor, is this: I believe the Court said at different times whether an appropriate remedy can be fashioned.
The Court did not say for whom.
It didn't say it must be for everybody.
It didn't say what would be necessary to trigger the right to the hearing.
It didn't say how much time would elapse.

It left -- it did leave, in that sense, everything open, but by leaving everything open, it also allows the court to narrow the categories of people who would be entitled to this hearing that -- in such a way that it would be an effective practical remedy.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.

turn.speaker: thomas_peters
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Peters
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Castiglione, why don't you take 3 minutes?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
Well, Your Honor, initially, two of the claimants here lost their property.
They defaulted.
Three had their property returned.
This is not a case where the matter -- the underlying matter is concluded by voluntary cessation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought they didn't.
I thought some didn't have it returned, but there was a settlement.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: One did, Your Honor, but it wasn't in response to the Federal litigation.
So our position would be if this is moot, this is really -- Munsingwear would apply.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The mootness was not a result of any settlement between the city and--

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: That's correct.
Well, I mean -- it didn't settle because of the lawsuit.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Your -- your friend said the opposite.
I mean--

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Well, it settled, Your Honor, just as through a normal course.
It was not a response to the Federal litigation that was going on independently.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I don't understand.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Well, I'm--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They got all of their property back?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: --Oh, no, no.
In most cases, yes, Your Honor.
The private -- the hearing -- the cases went to hearing and the three -- with the three car owners and they ultimately received their cars back.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, I don't understand.
They got their cars back, right?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The people who had money at stake, what happened to the money?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Two of them -- two defaulted and one reached a settlement with the State.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A settlement?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you have at least one case where the mootness is attributable to a settlement.
You have at least one plaintiff, and you can't get the kind of remand for mootness that you are asking for.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: No, I understand, Your Honor.
I'm just making the point that if this case -- if the Court finds it's moot, that we would want -- would ask for an entry of an order vacating the orders below pursuant to -- pursuant to Munsingwear.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But we don't do Munsingwear orders where -- where the mootness is a result of a settlement.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Our position, Your Honor, is that the settlement wasn't in response.
We didn't settle the Federal -- we didn't settle the Federal litigation.
The -- the underlying forfeiture case was -- was resolved.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I thought your answer is that they didn't all settle.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: They all didn't settle.
That's right.
In fact, that's a better answer, I think, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what good would a Munsingwear order do, anyway?
They'll just file another lawsuit, won't they?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: They could.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: They certainly could, if you -- they have the right to do that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And then if the district judge said -- having read this opinion, which was vacated, says, well, I guess it states a cause of action, I will deny the motion to dismiss -- we would be exactly where we are now.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: We -- and we would.
There is no doubt about that.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Can I just get clarification?
Under your State law, there is no way for an owner to come in and challenge probable cause to seize?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: There--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Not a defense--

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --but the examples Judge Breyer said: My car was just sitting there.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: There is not, Your Honor.
I mean, the forfeiture is not going to help.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: All right.

And, second, is there any procedure under your State law to do the second half of what your adversary said he was looking for, a remission-type proceeding that would balance the government's need to hold the property and the individual's need for it, and whether there is a bond that could be posted or not?

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Not that we -- Illinois doesn't provide for a bond, Your Honor.
As we indicated, there are problems with bonds, certainly for cash and for -- and for other personal property as well, but--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Well, that may be part of the Mathews issue, that once you prove probable cause, giving away -- giving back money just never would probably be rational to hold a hearing about, but that might not be true for real property, correct?
Under -- even under Mathews, under -- in a Mathews analysis.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: --I'm not sure I understand Your Honor's question.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: If you apply a Mathews analysis--

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --the multifaceted item would say for the seizure of cash, maybe only the hearing has to address probable cause, but for real property it has to go further.
Not real property, in the sense of real personal property.
It has to go further, because there has to be some sort of protection of the interest of the individual, pending--

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: Let me attempt to address that.

The -- the statute does contemplate, Your Honor, section -- especially section 6 of DAFPA, nonjudicial remedies, and then essentially if the amount of property is under 20,000 or if we are dealing with a car, which falls under section 6, those cases are routinely dealt with by negotiation, Your Honor.
And I think that's the best way to deal with hardship -- the hardship examples given -- is that both through negotiation and a speedy hearing--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Counsel.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: paul_castiglione
turn.label: Mr. Paul A. Castiglione
turn.text: --Thank you, Your Honor.
